page.lettertext:
fol.240r
May it please yo
r
good L. I have sent w
t
this
letter
e abbreviat of a muster, w
ch
was lately
taken of
e companies,
at are under
S
r
Francis
Vere
. They have bin many waies diminished
by
e service of this sommer, as will be written
to yo
r
L. by S
r
Francis himself: but by no-
thing so muche, as by their running away, sins
warning was given for their going into
France.
For w
ch
I am persuaded,
at they will be many
fewer, at their comming to
Flushing,
and have
taken therfor order,
at they shall at their arrival
be mustered againe. S
r
Francis Vere, and
e
Captaines are gone thither already, and attend
e
comming of
e companies: w
ch
have bin stopped
these 12 daies, through
e roughnes of
e winde,
w
ch
is against them at this present: w
ch
I thinke
in like maner is
e stay of my letters,
at have bin
written in
at behalf. I have signified
in my last, w
at
order I have taken, for supplie of
e companies,
at are appointed
out of
Berghen
.
Bergh
e
As yet I doe not knowe, howe
e
states of Ze-
land
doe digest it. But I make full account,
that they will use but smalle delay. Having
sent to
e campe, for
S
r
Nicholas Parkers
officers to
prepare his horseband for
Britaine,
as yet I have
S
r
Nicholas
kers
b
a
d of horss men
receaved no answear againe, but S
r
Nicholas
himself in comming out of
England,
hath passed by
the Hage, and I have signified unto him her
Ma
ties
pleasure: who is also ready to perfourme as muche
as is required. He doth onely request to have some
fol.240v
time for his souldiers, having bin in
e field for
5 monethes together, to repare their furniture.
He alleageth besides
at many of his troupe being
Dutche, and divers of them maried (as there
Dutch
marryed m
e
are in like maner, in
S
r
John Poleis
company) he
shall hardly be able to induce them to goe w
t
him:
and those
at shall be wonne, will be craving of
time, to make their provision. And where I have
persuaded him, to exchange w
t
S
r
John Poley, and to
exch
a
ged of S
r
John Polly
take some others in
e places of those
at are maried,
and are lothe to depart, he affirmeth
at
e most
of
e horses, w
ch
are of his company, are bought by
himself, as he thinkes S
r
John Poley will pretend
the very same, and
at in comming to exchange,
they shall hardly come to agree, in
e valuing of
their horses one against an other. Moreover
there is no
imprest appointed to be given to his
a
i
prest /
company to make provision for their victuals, and
all other necessaries, as there is unto
e footmen.
For nothing hath bin written, to my self about it, and
e officer of
e Treasurer hath receaved no order.
Lastly it is some grief to S
r
Nicholas Parker,
at ha-
ving alwaies commaunded under
S
r
Francis Vere
,
he should falle in his credit to a lower degree,
and having no charge be c
o
maunded
by an other
,
whome he thinkes he must serve but for a garde of
assurance. I have answeared these ob-
jections aswell as I could, and I have written to
e
Councel, and to
Count Maurice
, to graunt him a
Passeport to come unto Berghen, to put his troupe
in order, and to make their provision. I have
fol.241r
also promised, if neede shall require, to be an
indifferent arbiter between him and S
r
Poley, in
the passing of their horses from one to an other:
at
I trust I shall prevent all occasion of contention.
Heere is nothing yet concluded, for any
further imploiment of their forces in
e field: albeit
they have bin long in consultation about it. Their
opinions, I heare, are very divers therein.
Some doe hold it best, to send
e souldiers for a time
to refreshe themselves in their garrisons. Others
would proceede to
e taking of
Grolle
and
Oldenzeel,
and other smalle townes in
e
Twente
and
Drente
.
Their are also some
at would endevo
r
to blocke up
all
e passages
at laid unto
Groeninghen,
w
ch
they
make an easie mater. It is proposed by some
others,
at they should give an attempt upon the
towne of
Bolduke:
or make a bridge to passe
e
Rhine by
Sgravenwert
and so by skouring
at
coast, to hinder
e returne of
e Enemies forces,
w
ch
are thought to be as yet, w
t
e chiefest of
their strength, about Oldenzeal: attending, as
it seemeth, w
at
we will resolve.
The state is somw
at
troubled w
t
Count Mau-
rices courses. For although it be so
at he hath
spedde very happely in this enterprise of
Coe-
voerden
, yet
e expense of time and of mony
hath bin excessive, and might have bin lessened
in many respectes, if he would have obeied
e states
resolution. For w
ch
I finde by their speeches,
at if
he had missed of taking
e place, they would have
shortned his autoritie in sundrie special pointes: as
fol.241v
it may be peradventure they intend to doe as yet.
For sins
e winning of
e castel
he hath c
o
mitted
e custody of it to
e states
of
Friseland
: against
an expresse charge to
e contrary from
e
Coun-
cel of estate
, and directly, as
ei say, against his
othe as gouverno
r
of
Overyssel,
to whome, as all men
affirme, it ought in all reason, to have bin delive-
red. Wherat not onely they, but
e rest of
e Pro-
vinces doe greatly repine, reputing it an act
both inconsiderat and daungerous. For besides
e putting of variance betweene
e two Provinces,
w
ch
have lived of late, for other like occasions, in
very badde neighbourehood, it will sette
e Province
of Frise in so great a securitie in regard of
e Enemie,
that suche as are acquainted w
t
e humo
r
of the
people, doe thinke assuredly,
at being men full of
stomacke, opposit in their dealinges, over sparing
in their charges, and in all their proceedinges very
wilfully bent, they will not for heereafter be con-
tributo
rs
to
e warres, but in suche a proportion
as they list themselves. I am half
of opinion, and many men thinke it certaine,
at
upon this departure of
e Englishe companies, and
the contreis pretense,
at
e Contract is broken,
they will not long continue this Councel of Estate,
but take some other forme of gouvernment.
Howbeit because they stand in some hope,
at her Ma
tie
doth but purpose to w
t
drawe them for a time, they
may happely differ their intended
innovation.
Moreover I am persuaded,
at they would be well
contented, to make a
motion to her Ma
tie
or to hearken
fol.242r
rather to her Ma
tie
if it should in her behalf be
proposed unto them,
at they might heereafter be as-
sisted, w
t
e imprest
of some mony, and w
t
a great
deale lesser summe, then is spent by her Hig
nes
at
this present: or in some suche other sort, as bothe her
Ma
tie
may be eased in
e burden of her charges, and
e contrey relieved w
t
a competent aide. Whiche
I write unto yo
r
L. but onely by conjecture, not
having bin moved in
e mater by any. And
astouching
e dissolving of
e Councel of estate,
considering howe farre their autoritie is abrid-
ged, it can be nothing prejudicial to any purpose
of her Ma
tie
. For where
e Treaty doth ordene,
at
e Gouverno
r
general for her Ma
tie
and
e Councel
of estate shall order all affaires appertaining to
e
warres, and to
e gouvernment of
e contrey, her
Ma
tie
undoubtedly by
at course might receave, be-
ing duly put in practise, a very singular bene-
fit. But there is nothing nowe perfourmed of
all
at was contracted, but onely in an outward
formal shewe,
e states assuming to themselves
e
direction of every action. I receave
at this instant a letter from
Count Maurice
wher-
Cont Mauryce
l
re
for
S
r
Nicholas
ker
in is signified unto me,
at he hath retained
e
horseband of S
r
Nicholas Parker, upon hope
at her Ma
tie
being informed of
e great discommoditie, w
ch
e
contrey shall receave, through
e losse of his c
o
pany,
wherof he praieth me earnestly to advertise her Hig
nes
she will change her forsaid purpose. I have sent
heere w
t
all
e
copie of his letter
: and by one of the
Councel, w
ch
came from Swol unto
e Hage, I have
bin instantly moved in
e name of all the rest,
fol.242v
to
e same effect as
e Count hath written.
Wherupon considering w
t
my self, howe muche
e
contrey is grieved already,
at
e footmen are w
t
-
drawen, I have thought it very meete for her Ma
ties
better service, to give them some content, and to stay
the urging of
e mater, till I heare once againe howe
her Ma
tie
is affected: w
ch
I am also constrained
to attend of necessitie, for
at
e company till then,
will be hardly put in readines. Howbeit as yo
r
L may perceave by
e writing of
e Count, if her
Ma
tie
in her purpose, to have
e company away, con-
tinue still resolut, there will be no resistance.
There are also sent unto me, from
e
Councel of estate 3 intercepted
Englishe letters
,
3 Eng
l
l
re
s
of w
ch
I have sent yow
e originals heerew
t
.
They were taken from one,
at was comming from
Collen,
w
t
divers other Spanishe and Italian l
re
s,
of w
ch
one was from
Rome
from
e
Spanish Am-
bassado
r
, and was written in ciphers, and is com-
mitted to one
at will travel to decipher it:
and likewise those wordes,
at are written in cipher
in
e Englishe letters. Whatsoever shall be found,
shall be signified to yo
r
L. The rest of
e
letters in Italian and spanishe contened litle
mater, but of
e comming to
Paris
of
e
D.of Fe-
ria
, of
e election towardes of
e liguers kinge,
and of cartels gone abroade between
Parma
and
Mantua,
and
e
Marquis of Guasto
. There
was one of
Collen
among
e rest,
at had written
divers letters to
Andwerp,
and
Brussels,
w
t
out
putting to his name, and used those wordes, w
ch
I
send yo
r
L. in a schedule, in 3 of his letters, w
ch
me thinkes may import, as if they looked out of
England, for some newes extraordinarie.
And thus I take my h
u
ble leave. From
e Hage. 7
ber
21
1592.
Yo
r
L most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
Heere is a constant bruite
at this present,
at
e
Lantgrave
of Hesse
is deceased./
